questions.question: Which World Wonder, located in the desert in the Middle East, was built as a tomb for the pharaoh around 2560 BC and is the only surviving structure of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World?
questions.context: This pyramid stands as a testament to ancient engineering and attracts millions of tourists each year.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Europe was one of the earliest Roman amphitheaters built, dating back to 27 BC, and is known for its large-scale gladiatorial games?
questions.context: This iconic structure could host up to 80,000 spectators and remains one of the most visited historical landmarks in the world.

questions.question: Which historical battle site in North America, known for a pivotal 1777 conflict during the American Revolutionary War, is noted for being a turning point that brought France into the war on the American side?

answer.label: Saratoga National Historical Park, New York, USA

questions.context: The American victory at this site convinced France that the American cause was worth supporting.

questions.question: Which ancient ruin in South America, known for its intricately carved stone temples, was constructed by the Inca around 1450 and mysteriously abandoned a century later?
questions.context: This archeological site is renowned for its stunning views and well-preserved architecture.

questions.question: Which capital city, the northernmost in Scandinavia, is known for its iconic harbor and is part of a country famous for its fjords and Viking heritage?
questions.context: This city hosts the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony each year and its beautiful waterfront is a major attraction.
